answers.author: Jesse Himes
answers.text:
Hey Abigail,
Here’s a couple of things that may help in your search for unique food stories.
Williamsburg, VA now accepts SNAP at its farmers market. The article goes into more detail but it’s definitely interesting. http://icma.org/en/Article/103428/Williamsburg_VA_Farmers_Market_Accepts_SNAP
Also, the city of High Springs came up with some great ideas to promote Community Gardens to replace vacant lots around the city.
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/100118/City_of_High_Springss_Farmers_Market
I hope this helped!
Jesse Himes, Knowledge Network Intern, jhimes@icma.org

author: Abigail Lundy
text:
Working with your local farmers' market? Updating your zoning to allow for new grocery stores, urban chickens, or rooftop bees? Procuring only locally grown foods in municipal buildings? Providing curbside composting?
ICMA's Center for Sustainable Communities is writing a series of case studies highlighting the variety of different efforts local governments have undertaken to strengthen their local food economy and food systems, and to address issues of food access and insecurity. If you're interested in being profiled, please contact Abigail Lundy (alundy@icma.org) with a brief email outlining the efforts you're involved with.
Hope to hear from many of you! In the meantime, learn more about ICMA's existing research, and other resources, on food systems here: http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/topic/296.
title: Have a good food story in your community?
